text.0: Try the full #InfoFinder quiz: https://t.co/UXwmB3d2V5 or visit #InfoFinder: https://t.co/UW5o3cTA2P
text.1: The correct answer to our #quiz question is: False. Boko Haram was ranked by the Global Terrorism Index as the second deadliest terrorist group in the world in 2019, but remains the deadliest in sub-Saharan Africa.
text.2: 5. Empower people to identify & recognise false information on social media. Campaigns that focus on users’ personal control of misinformation may make them feel less anxious and overwhelmed. https://t.co/CXCXjJIPiX
text.3: 4. Many fact-checkers already follow media and other partnership models to achieve greater impact and reach. Involving government departments of health, civil society organisations and vetted religious leaders could be further explored. https://t.co/CXCXjK0qav
text.4:
Ep 33 of the "What's Crap on WhatsApp?" podcast:
:nail_polish_medium_skin_tone: Is there a nail polish that can detect date-rape drugs in a drink?
:coffin_selector: Do these photos show graves submerged beneath South Africa’s Vaal Dam?
https://t.co/uFlAiwBfkF @AfricaCheck @mcnallypm @kateomega
text.5: Fack checking groups @dubawaNG, @AfricaCheck, @AFPFactCheck, @PesaCheck @meedan - part of @WHO's Africa Infodemic Response Alliance - launch initiative to tackle the spread of COVID-19 misinformation on the continent: https://t.co/B6wZmcoqSE
text.6: Thank you to the Mauritius Society Renewal, @AfricaCheck and University of Mauritius for your partnership on this workshop on fact checking! Identifying and stopping the spread of misinformation ensures that credible news sources maintain trust. :United_States::Mauritius: https://t.co/Pn13bL5o7A
text.7: 3. Tap into trusted personal networks. We learned users were more likely to share or act on information received from within a trusted personal network. Harnessing these connections is key to spreading accurate information. https://t.co/CXCXjJIPiX
text.8: 2. Respondents in our survey said they shared Covid-19 info because they wanted to raise awareness & provide helpful information to people they cared about. Guiding the public to be helpful in a time of crisis by providing accurate info is essential. https://t.co/CXCXjK0qav
text.9: 1. Understand the different risks posed by false information. Though Covid-19 has largely been treated as a health crisis, the evidence suggests there is a mental health crisis following close behind, in which #misinformation plays an active role. https://t.co/CXCXjK0qav
text.10:
:newspaper: Recovery from the #COVID19 pandemic has been slowed by a global flood of #misinformation about the disease, its impact & potential resolution. 

Here are 5 ways fact-checkers in #Africa can tackle this “infodemic”. https://t.co/CXCXjJIPiX
